column4: Is there a way to open an additional instance of a GUI program (in this case, my database administration tool)?  Normally clicking on it in the launcher opens a maximum of one instance.
Would it be specific to each program?  I'm working with pgadmin3 for postgresql on ubuntu 12.04.
try middle-clicking
thank you!  I don't have a middle button configured on my mouse
try clicking the left and right at the same time, it should emulate a middle mouse click

Thanks again -- no result from the "both buttons click".  Maybe I should pursue the mouse click emulation first?  Is it the default of the 12.04 launcher to open additional application instances on middle-click?
it should be. there may also be a right-click menu option to open another instance (I don't have my 12.04 machine in front of me)

If the launcher's right-click menu for this particular app doesn't contain any option for opening an additional instance, is that then just something the app itself doesn't offer?  If that's likely then maybe I won't overly trouble myself over this.
which application?
pgadmin3 -- it's the GUI admin client for postgreSQL.
naturally I asked in #postgresql but they're not too big on the GUI client ;)
hmm, never used it. try it with firefox, if you get firefox to do it but not your tool, then it may be the tool
yes, Firefox offers an "open a new window" option -- that's one of the data points that made me think that offering that option or not is on a per-application basis in Ubuntu
then it could very well be an application limitation. try contacting the developer of the GUI
and of course the default Terminal application does as well, that was my other hint
yes, thanks again.  That's it for now!
no problem
I overlooked the obvious! ahaha.  /usr/bin/pgadmin3 launches an additional instance without complaint or error.
well, there you go then :)
actually, if running the command again works, then turning on middle-mouse-button-emulation will probably work!
I think the "second window" and "second terminal" items in firefox & terminal are ADDED by the applications.
I see, thanks

yesterday, when I thought CCSM and other tweak tools were failing to adjust my Launcher opacity... it was just that the launcher was black over black background, and Unity's launcher has a certain minimum opacity (i.e. maximum transparency) limit that interacted with that to make it appear as if no change was made.
